articles.title: Scientists Chance Upon 90000 Year Old Human Footprints On Moroccan Beach
articles.excerpt: Multiple footprints discovered in Larache Morocco are among the earliest attributed to Homo sapiens worldwide
articles.summary: Some 90000 years ago a group of humans walked across a sandy beach in the city of Larache on Morocco 's northwest coast Remarkably archaeologists have found a large number of intact footprints from the journey These represent the oldest human prints found in the region and among the earliest attributed to Homo sapiens worldwide Footprints represent moments frozen in time that can reveal fascinating details on everything from stature age and body mass to speed gait and social behavior After studying 85 of the most well preserved fossilized prints found in Larache the international team of researchers concluded they were made by at least five people including children an adolescent and adults They detail their findings in a new study published in the journal Scientific Reports This is an exciting discovery and it adds to other evidence that the Middle Stone Age inhabitants of Morocco were visiting the coast presumably in search of food and other items Louise Humphrey a bioarchaelogist with London 's Natural History Museum who was not involved with the research said over email Scientists stumbled upon the footprints in 2022 While on a field mission studying boulders on a rocky beach they noticed an indentation in the ground and closer inspection revealed more of them In the study they describe how they identified the markings as footprints based on anatomical characteristics reflective of human feet such as a rounded heel a plantar arch and relatively short toes And they detail how they dated the rock containing the footprints using optically stimulated luminescence a cutting edge technique that measures when materials such as grains of sand last absorbed sunlight Morocco is also home to the Jebel Irhoud archaeological site where scientists discovered the earliest known fossilized remains of homo sapiens dating back 300000 years The oldest known homo sapiens footprints found in South Africa date back 153000 years The Larache researchers believe their footprints survived many millenia at least in part because they 're located in a spot where a large boulder partially protects them from wave swells that would erode the site over time The last 90000 years have seen around 78 feet of sediment deposited above the level of the footprints Mouncef Sedrati a life sciences professor at France 's University of South Brittany and a co author of the study said in an interview It is conceivable that in recent years with the frequent occurrence of storms the cliff of which the layer of footprints constitutes the current base started to erode Sedrati said Consequently the rocky platform began to peel away layer by layer until it reached its present level revealing the footprints in the process It 's unknown what exactly the ancient humans were doing on the beach They could have just been passing through along two trails But since our Pleistocene predecessors were hunter gatherers and past studies have shown the importance of coastal regions for their resource gathering they likely were foraging for food The orientation of their footprints perpendicular to the coastline suggests a search for a marine meal The researchers hypothesize that the children present in the group may have aided in that hunt though further studies will be needed to validate this theory What is particularly exciting about this discovery is the entire paleontological and paleoanthropological potential it provides Sedrati said We have only examined the best preserved 85 footprints Dozens more human and potentially animal prints remain to be explored and studied
articles.author: Leslie Katz

articles.title: InnovationRx Healthcare Software Is n't Eating The World Yet
articles.excerpt: InnovationRx is your weekly digest of healthcare news Sign up
articles.summary: InnovationRx is your weekly digest of healthcare news To get it in your inbox subscribe here Venture capital investors are obsessed with software businesses and healthcare is no different The idea being that software equals the biggest opportunities with the highest profit margin and the greatest return on investment compared to more labor intensive services businesses But when Sam Toole and Marisa Bass early stage healthcare investors at Primary recently surveyed the IPOs and M&A exits of digital health unicorns over the past decade the results were surprising We would have thought that the software side would be way more efficient in terms of that enterprise value creation versus services Toole told Forbes But that was n't the case even though healthcare software businesses had wildly outsized valuations over the past few years When looking at total dollars raised divided by valuation on the public or private markets the return for companies providing healthcare services was 4.7x while companies selling software to health insurers and health systems came in at 3.8x according to the Primary analysis There 's one big caveat here the analysis looked at companies started after 2010 which means neither Veeva Systems nor Livongo was part of the analysis As the IPO drought continues and startups have to raise more and more money early stage investors can end up getting shafted if they do n't participate in future fundraises That 's why Toole and Bass are starting to think about non traditional funding structures including tranche investments such as co leading rounds with bigger later stage VCs and giving the startup access to more money over time as it hits certain milestones The question Toole and Bass posed was whether early stage investors should even invest in healthcare companies And they 're not throwing in the towel just yet Toole believes the market is finally at a tipping point more than a decade after the HITECH Act spurred the march towards electronic health records As health systems continue to be squeezed by cost pressures including labor shortages they are going to be looking to technology as a driver of efficiency He believes we 're at a tipping point of combining underlying technology with providers who are finally willing to adopt it But the hardest thing was with venture investing he said is if you 're wrong from a timing perspective it does n't matter CrowdHealth wants you to ditch traditional health insurance for a new approach to managing expenses It 's won over bitcoiners but will it work for everyone The company has signed up 7000 members and they each pay $ 50 a month so it 's heading toward $ 4 million in annual revenue It does n't accept members who smoke or men who weigh over 260 pounds or women who weigh over 220 pounds Pipeline Deal Updates Home Health Coral Care a startup offering in home developmental care for kids has raised $ 1.3 million from investors including Reach Capital and Hustle Fund The startup recruits and vets speech language pathologists occupational therapists and physical therapists Telehealth Boulder Care a startup that provides virtual substance use disorder treatment is expanding its services to teens through a value based contract with UnitedHealthcare Community Plan of Washington a Medicaid health plan that serves low income families Teens under 18 seeking treatment for opioid or alcohol use disorders will be eligible for the program Autoimmune Disease Genentech has entered into a multi year research agreement with San Francisco based genetic medicine company GenEdit to develop nanoparticles to deliver drugs for autoimmune diseases The deal includes a $ 15 million upfront payment to GenEdit up to $ 629 million more in milestone payments and tiered royalties on any drugs that go to market AI Diagnostics Dutch company Thirona announced that its AI clinical software LungQ which analyzes CT images of the lungs has been cleared by the FDA for use in the United States M&A Sanofi announced that it 's acquiring biotech company Inhibrix with an aim to acquire INBRX-101 a drug candidate for Alpha-1 Anytrypsin Deficiency The deal is estimated to be worth about $ 1.7 billion As part of the arrangement certain parts of Inhibrix related to other assets besides INBRX-101 will be spun off into a new company Healthcare Pricing Turquoise Health a platform aimed at improving price transparency in healthcare announced it has raised a $ 30 million series B investment led by Adams Street Partners What You Need To Know About Measles After WHO Sounds Alarm Over Killer Virus In Europe Health officials around the world are scrambling to combat a rising tide of measles as falling vaccination rates and increased travel after the Covid-19 pandemic help the dangerous virus stage an alarming comeback with countries in Europe declaring national emergencies as U.S. experts monitor growing cases at risk of spiraling into bigger outbreaks Other Healthcare News Appeals court upholds Pharma Bro Martin Shkreli 's lifetime ban from the pharmaceutical industry Elevance Health reports $ 856 million fourth quarter profit despite drop In Medicaid enrollment Abbott says its baby formula franchise is back to leading the U.S. market after plant shutdowns led to widespread shortages study found anxiety and depression symptoms jumped in the U.S. after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade Across Forbes
articles.author: Katie Jennings

articles.title: Groundhog Day movie The Buddhist lifehacker film
articles.excerpt: Harold Ramis 1993 movie Groundhog Day is so entertaining you 'll want to see it again and again and again Explore meanings and central themes in the movie
articles.summary: It 's not true that life is one damn thing after another it 's one damn thing over and over Edna St. Vincent Millay I 've seen the 1993 film Groundhog Day again and again and again but only once on the big screen a few years after it was in theaters It was shown in a packed lecture hall inside Baltimore 's Walters Art Museum followed by a lecture from a comparative religion scholar who took us through the spiritual meaning and symbolism cleverly packaged in what on its surface is a rom com with a Twilight Zone premise Even if you have n't seen the film you still know the basic plot because the term Groundhog Day has entered the common vernacular which alone speaks to its resonance beyond the film itself as shorthand for repeating the same experience over and over But it 's worth seeing for the first time or the tenth to witness self centered weatherman Phil Connors a role only Bill Murray could master breaking that cycle through personal redemption It 's a grand metaphor some scholars see as Buddhist Christian or secularly philosophical It 's also directly practically applicable to how you spend your day today and everyday I think the film is best described as Buddish an adjective coined by the film 's director Harold Ramis to sum up his own belief system His mother in law and one of his best friends were devout Zen Buddhists who hooked him onto its precepts Memorable simple did n't require articles of faith but completely humanistic in every way that I valued he said in aninterview for Chicago magazinein 2008 So I proselytize it without practicing it And what an entertaining Buddish proselytization Groundhog Day is Like sushi or a Jamba Juice shake it 's so delicious you barely realize you 're eating raw fish and fruit That 's the reason for this metaphysical movie 's enduring cult status a genuinely hilarious film that glimpses the meaning of life There are many theories about Phil 's temporal loop which by one estimatelasted nearly 34 years and his eventual escape One sees it as ametaphor for psychotherapy repeating the stories of one 's past until you have a breakthrough that allows you to dismantle old patterns Another claims it illustrates aclassic economic paradigm But the most wisdom invoking evidence amounts to religious insight and how to most fruitfully spend our precious hours One of the central tenets of Buddhism is that we must continue to reincarnate until we find enlightenment The concept called samsara keeps us living out many lives through various modes of existence called gati some lowly animals and others god like as determined by your actions karma Once ignorance and ego are destroyed by your actions and awareness you awaken to the true interconnected reality which frees you from the cycle and into heavenly nirvana In the film written by Danny Rubin a Zen Buddhist according to Ramis DVD commentary of the film Phil reincarnates each day but he also transforms his behavior over time He takes self centered advantage of his unique predicament robbing bank trucks stuffing his face with angel food cake tricking a woman into bed but eventually perfects the day with creative self improvement tasks and compassionately helping others Once he becomes the best possible version of Phil Connors he is released from his temporal prison while simultaneously winning the love of his virtuous producer Rita Phil 's plight is not unlike a character from Greek mythology who was doomed to eternally and perpetually push a boulder up a mountain In his essay The Myth of Sisyphus Albert Camus uses the story to illustrate the absurdity of lives that toil away at meaningless jobs But Camus says we must find hope and therefore meaning in such a plight and he imagines Sisyphus understanding and accepting it There 's a similar Buddhist tale of an enlightened monk who climbs a mountain to get a spoonful of snow in order to fill a well at the bottom of the mountain again and again Some lessons take a long and seemingly futile amount of time to learn Buddhist monasticism is itself Groundhog'-like with the same routine clothes and daily rituals for decades of practice Yet every moment is still different Remember what the ancient Greek philosopher Heraclitus said No man ever steps in the same river twice for it 's not the same river and he 's not the same man In that sense Phil does n't repeat the same day over and over because one significant thing is different each Groundhog Day him He is the one thing that is changing What is time anyway Illusory says Buddhist dogma a notion contained in the Zen koan Phil asks as he begins to understand that his own time is not progressing What if there is no tomorrow There was n't one today That 's right woodchuck chuckers there is no past or future There is only now The Catholic concept of purgatory a spiritual realm where souls must linger until they expiate their remaining sins and earn their way into heaven fits the film 's bill as much as the Buddhist concept samsara And many references and motifs that recur in the film support the notion that Groundhog Day is Christian rather than Buddhist These sticky buns are heaven When you stand in the snow you look like an angel Thegroundhog hibernation rebirth after a death of sorts and emerging from the sleepy tomb is reminiscent of Jesus There 's even a delightfully blasphemous scene in which Phil declares that he isagod I 'm nottheGod I do n't think he wonders aloud as he contemplates how close he comes to the Catholic conception of monotheism Maybe he 's not omnipotent He 's just been around so long he knows everything This after he has shouted like an angry deity I make the weather Then there 's the film 's montage with a homeless man whom Phil brushes off early on patting his pants pockets like he does n't have any cash Later Phil tries to help repeatedly only to find the man dies every time It 's the lesson of the Serenity Prayer written by the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr and later co opted by Alcoholics Anonymous God grant me the serenity to accept the things I can not change The courage to change the things I can And the wisdom to know the difference After accepting that he can not save the old man Phil turns an optimistic and meaningful corner in the plot and begins living in service to others catching a falling boy from a tree saving the mayor from choking etc It 's this change of direction that allows him to escape purgatory Whatever spiritual takeaway the film holds for you it 's an undeniable call for hope Phil survives his many attempts at suicide leaping from a church dropping a toaster in the tub driving off a cliff and is reborn a hopeful charitable man Baptized by death and stronger for it on the other side he tells his television audience When Chekhov saw the long winter he saw a winter bleak and dark and bereft of hope Yet we know that winter is just another step in the cycle of life Winter is such a great metaphor for the bleakness that precedes rebirth I 'll give you a winter prediction the weatherman reports in the hopeless second act of the film It 's gon na be cold it 's gon na be gray and it 's gon na last you for the rest of your life But in a more optimistic stage he wakes up one happy morning and surprises a stranger with a hug and a Samuel Coleridge quote Winter slumbering in the open air wears on its smiling face a dream of spring It 's from the sonnet Work Without Hope which contains the famous line bloom for whom ye may which Phil does This is the classic hero 's journey Phil is exiled into an unexpected adventure despairs suffers losses but eventually learns how to overcome his obstacles and hopelessness By the end of the film he has managed to become the town hero for all the mitzvah he crams into a single day You do n't have to subscribe to Buddhism or Christianity or believe in reincarnation or heaven for this story to be directly applicable to your daily life What would you do if you were stuck in one place and every day was exactly the same and nothing that you did mattered Phil asks a townie Ralph in the film That about sums it up for me says Ralph And who does n't relate at one time or another for one day or many years to that sentiment It 's Thoreau 's life of quiet desperation It 's Sisyphus It 's George Baileypre epiphany in It 's a Wonderful Life I think people place too much emphasis on their careers Phil says to Rita I wish we could all live in the mountains at high altitude That 's where I see myself in five years How about you This sentiment echoes an earlier role in Murray 's career as Larry Darrell in the movie based on the novel by W. Somerset Maugham The Razor 's Edge Darrell takes a pilgrimage to find enlightenment with Tibetan monks high in the Himalayas where he observes that It 's easy to be a holy man on top of a mountain The rest of us are down here in the valley where it 's harder Each day is not that different than the last We 're on autopilot sometimes We 're bored We repeat our bad habits We are often self centered and usually under inspired But something does change every day even if it 's imperceptible It 's ourselves And we can choose how this day will unfold and how we will slowly evolve There might even be a Groundhog Day'-inspired resolution memorizing French poetry playing the piano figuring out how to help others more often Like Phil we can utilize creativity and compassion to change aglass is half empty paradigm to half full The pursuit of meaning is itself meaningful And today as well as everyday can be your first day of spring Sign up for CNN 's Stress But Less newsletter Our six part mindfulness guidewill inform and inspire you to reduce stress while learning how to harness it
articles.author: David G. Allan

articles.title: Clips of shark attacks plane crashes rough seas we hate to love them
articles.excerpt: Videos of shark attacks plane crashes rough seas we hate them but we ca n't look away
articles.summary: Before boarding a flight Simon watches videos of plane crashes Recently while preparing to go snorkeling in Thailand he looked up videos of shark attacks Wp Get the full experience Choose your plan ArrowRight Why would I do that says Simon a communications professional in Brooklyn These videos give me anxiety yet they 're kind of soothing It 's like sucking on a canker sore Simon would discuss this topic only if we did n't use his real name because Simon does n't relish the idea of friends and co workers knowing that he watches disaster videos for recreation I do n't know why I 'm drawn to it Simon says It 's really sick But internet algorithms feed him more If they do n't he feeds himself You 're tapping into this pure raw almost primal instinct that you do n't get in your day to day life he says It makes you feel more alive to stare death in the face Advertisement Simon sends me a few of these videos One shows a tiger shark clamp its jaws around a 23 year old Russian tourist Another shows a 747 cargo plane that seems to hang motionless in the air for several seconds then flips over and races to the ground The explosion on impact looks like something out of a Michael Bay movie but it 's real And it haunts Simon But in a pleasing way In terms of plane crashes he says it 's hard to pick a favorite The videos make me never want to fly or swim again But I re watch them Why We want to understand death says Cynthia Hoffner a Georgia State University professor who studies the psychological aspects of media use We 're all going to die at some point Curiosity about that is part of human life Skip to end of carousel The Style section Style is where The Washington Post covers happenings on the front lines of culture and what it all means including the arts media social trends politics and yes fashion all told with personality and deep reporting For more Style stories click here End of carousel I 'm more of a near tragedy guy myself I am terrified of the ocean depths And yet I end many nights watching videos of sinking ships Advertisement I am terrified of extreme heights And yet I begin many days watching urban climbers hang from skyscrapers by one hand Everybody rubbernecks On the highway and on the internet Videos of that door flying off the Alaska Airlines flight earlier this month racked up millions of views Did you look away Or did you watch enraptured and nauseous and imagine what it would feel like to be sucked from your seat and tossed into a 16000 foot free fall On Reddit more than 2.4 million users follow a subreddit titled r sweatypalms a clearinghouse for videos of near death experiences Whatever it is you fear you 're sure to find it here Here 's a cougar stalking a hiker for six minutes Here 's a spelunker pinned in the narrow crevasse of a cave Advertisement The subreddit 's moderators declined to comment because none of us are qualified to be speaking on the human condition Fair One reason people seek these out says Hoffner is to overcome their fears In a safe context you can experience fear and desensitize yourself she says pointing out it 's a common treatment for phobias There are more specific subreddits if you 're addicted to a particular type of fear and perhaps want to conquer it On r acrophobia you can watch people dangling off cliff faces skyscrapers even the Eiffel Tower You 'll surely stumble up on the viral video from a GoPro camera on the head of a gentleman who climbs 2000 feet up a skinny radio tower to change the lightbulb at the top Filmmaker Scott Mann so enticed by the genre made a thriller titled Fall in which two climbers scale a similar tower and get stuck at the top For about 107 minutes they dangle and despair It 's horrifying It reportedly made back 580 percent of its budget at the box office Advertisement All our fears are baked into the question What if this happened to me says Mann The idea of your life hinging on something as minor as a squeaky bolt But it 's still a movie It 's still safe And that Mann suggests is what makes real life videos such as the one of Alaska Airlines so frightening Share this article Share The reason why the airplane video was particularly bad is because it was n't in the safety of the cinema he says It was reality And that makes it all the worse It 's real life and that 's what gets me But maybe heights are n't your thrill Dread the deep ocean Head over to r thalassophobia to join the 1.6 million people watching videos of shipwrecks deep sea life and divers having panic attacks Or head over to TikTok where the North Sea has been trending Yes the entire sea Clips show ships tossed around by massive waves and crew members brushing their teeth while being thrown from wall to wall Advertisement Christina Huber will never visit the North Sea but she is most definitely wholeheartedly terrified of the North Sea I live on Lake Michigan and I 've seen how treacherous the waters can get says Huber 29 a Chicago based podcast host who goes by Bravo Babe Amplify that to the hundredth and that 's what these people are experiencing on the North Sea Those ships nosedive straight into the water Our brains do n't care whether the probability is low that we 'll end up at the top of a radio tower or in the middle of the North Sea says Coltan Scrivner a behavioral scientist at the Recreational Fear Lab at Aarhus University and the department of psychology at Arizona State University Somebody found themselves in that situation And we often find ourselves in situations we never thought we would be in Scrivner says Your mind is still like Okay this is really important I should pay attention because what if Advertisement Scrivner conducted a study at the beginning of the pandemic and found that people who watched at least one movie about a pandemic such as Contagion had better psychological resilience than those who had not They 'd seen it play out before he says There was uncertainty but it was sort of expected uncertainty What about the people who actually film these sweaty palms videos Alexis Landot who 's 23 and lives in Paris learned to boulder when he was 8 years old when his father put him in a gym to burn off his excess energy Now he scales skyscrapers without safety equipment and records it Unlike his viewers he ca n't have sweaty palms when he 's climbing He actively tries to suppress the adrenaline that his fans crave He thinks his fans watch because they 'd never do it themselves Says Landot This is the closest they will feel to what I 'm doing Simon from Brooklyn might watch one of Landot 's videos as long as Landot does n't fall on a cat
articles.author: Travis M. Andrews

articles.title: Transcript Race in America Giving Voice with Aunjanue Ellis Taylor Actor Origin
articles.excerpt: Transcript Race in America Giving Voice with Aunjanue Ellis Taylor Actor Origin
articles.summary: MR CAPEHART Good afternoon and welcome to Washington Post Live and another in our series on Race in America co produced with the Capehart podcast I am Jonathan Capehart associate editor at The Washington Post Wp Get the full experience Choose your plan ArrowRight When Ava DuVernay 's movie Origin premiered at the Venice Film Festival last year it received a nine minute standing ovation The movie written and directed by Ava DuVernay is an adaptation of the bestselling book Caste The origins of Our Discontent by Isabel Wilkerson The film 's power is n't just driven by the subject matter It is driven by its lead actress Aunjanue Ellis Taylor and she joins me now Aunjanue thank you so much for being here Welcome to Washington Post Live MS ELLIS TAYLOR Thank you Thank you for having me MR CAPEHART So before we dive into the movie and your performance let 's talk about how your involvement came about In interviews Ava has said that she had been interviewing Isabel Wilkerson for two years to prepare for this film At what point did Ava approach you and what were those initial conversations like Advertisement MS ELLIS TAYLOR Well I kind of approached her actually MR CAPEHART Oh MS ELLIS TAYLOR I knew that I had heard that she was that she had adapted was adapting the book I just thought I knew the book right by reputation I had not read it yet but I just thought it was just this extraordinary thing that this extraordinary woman was going to do And when I heard that she was starting to cast it I said I want to be a part of that conversation And so I my sister and myself made a picture that sort of matched Ms. Wilkerson 's kind of iconic photo that she has of herself and we sent it to the casting director and the casting director sent it to Ms. DuVernay And then we started talking Laughter MR CAPEHART Okay So then you started talking You get the role but-- MS ELLIS TAYLOR I get the role Thank God Advertisement MR CAPEHART But Wilkerson is famously private I mean I 've been trying for three years since I got my MSNBC show to get her to come on my show just to talk about stuff and her books How did you approach playing her What did you do to prepare MS ELLIS TAYLOR Well one of the first conversations that I had with Ava about what she wanted to achieve with the film is that she was interested in dramatizing the interior life of a woman the interior life of a Black woman particularly a Black genius And that is something that you rarely see in American cinema particularly with women in general We do n't see the inner workings of a woman 's mind how she creates how she makes So that was fascinating to me and one of the reasons why I wanted to do it And then having seen Ms. Wilkerson 's interviews when Caste came out in 2020 this woman is a refined person right She is a wordsmith So her words are her currency It 's her strategy It 's how she moves through the world is a power of her words So what I had to do in lieu of meeting her because I did n't get a chance to meet her hopefully I will one day I had to study her I had to study her interviews I had to study her that famous TED Talk she did when Warmth of Other Suns came out I studied that over and over and over again and that was my source material Advertisement And I 'm sure you would attest to as well Jonathan that her writing one of the reasons probably why you want to talk to her is her writing is so brilliant and one of the reasons why her writing is so brilliant is that she 's so transparent in her approach to her subjects In other words she is always present in her writing her personal life Her own experiences are always present It makes her very accessible So I just went to her book and pulled out what I could from that book what I felt was her MR CAPEHART I 'm sorry I am I am speechless because here you play this as you call it Black genius MS ELLIS TAYLOR Yes MR CAPEHART And she 's so notoriously private that you have n't even met her yet MS ELLIS TAYLOR No I have n't I haven't-- MR CAPEHART Have you heard from her since the movie came out Advertisement MS ELLIS TAYLOR I have n't I have n't heard from her MR CAPEHART And so-- MS ELLIS TAYLOR I 'm terrified I 'm terrified I 'm terrified Can I just be honest I 'm terrified MR CAPEHART Wait Why MS ELLIS TAYLOR I 'm terrified because I you know when you I had this conversation a couple of weeks ago and someone was in the process of doing writing a biography I think it was Alexis Pauline Gumbs and she was talking about her biography work And in the process of that conversation I said I 'm a biographer on screen That is a responsibility That is a huge responsibility whether someone is dead or alive but someone who is still in so there's you know if someone is not around anymore not walking around you can really you can really go into the imagination Right MR CAPEHART Mm hmm Advertisement MS ELLIS TAYLOR But at this point this woman is walking around right now She 's present She 's writing She 's a part of our human she 's a part of our American conversation at this moment and the audacity of me-- Laughter MS ELLIS TAYLOR Do you know what I 'm saying MR CAPEHART Right MS ELLIS TAYLOR To attempt to portray this woman this huge force in our culture I 'm terrified I don't I do n't know what she thinks I have to not think about it but yes I 'm terrified MR CAPEHART Well I will say two things about that One she could not help but be proud of the performance you give of her You are the central the central character in this story and I want to get to that in a second But also I will tell you I interviewed the cast and a lot of the producers of the new NatGeo series Genius MLK X. Advertisement MS ELLIS TAYLOR Mm hmm MR CAPEHART And I asked Kelvin Harrison who plays Martin Luther King Jr you know how did it feel to play that role and he said he was terrified-- MS ELLIS TAYLOR Mm hmm MR CAPEHART --terrified to play such an historic figure So I just throw that out to you Dead or alive if you're if the person you 're portraying is a genius or a monumental figure terror comes with the role It comes with the role MS ELLIS TAYLOR Right right Because it just does n't belong to you It does n't just belong to you It belongs to of course them But also it belongs to the people who read her books who are inspired by her and I 'm one of them Yeah MR CAPEHART So let 's talk so let 's talk more about the book I 've read both Warmth of Other Suns and Caste and Warmth of Other Suns I could see immediately how that could be a movie But when it came to Caste it was you know the idea that that would be a movie given the thick subject matter was a little hard for me to wrap my head around until I saw how Ava DuVernay did it And she did it by making Isabel Wilkerson the focal point of this of the story there There is no real antagonist unless you look at Caste and her journey But talk to me about you know what it was like for you to be in a movie that is about a book where in the book the author is not the central character but in the movie the author is the central character And the journey to what became Caste is what the movie is about Advertisement MS ELLIS TAYLOR Well that 's a mark of the visionary work of Ava of Ava DuVernay In her research of with Ms. Wilkerson and talking to her interviewing her which also lasted several years a few years she found out or discovered really that Ms. Wilkerson herself is a compelling character I mean we know that But what she did n't know was what was happening in her personal life leading up to her writing this book and what was happening or what had happened was that she was experiencing she was experiencing incredible loss unbelievable loss losing three people in a very three of the most important people in her life in a very short amount of time And then she writes this book Right That changed that shifted how we think about race in this country how we think about social divisions in this country She went through that and then wrote this book Most of us would just be felled by that and we would n't get up ever again you know MR CAPEHART Right Advertisement MS ELLIS TAYLOR I know when I lost the love of my life I was silly for years and I 'm still going through it Anyway so Ava found our hero in Ms. Wilkerson and I had to embrace that idea And I just think of her as an Indiana Jones you know going around the world on this intellectual and journalistic quest and the boulder that 's behind her is this you know mammoth grief that is that she 's suffering from And yet she keeps going because her quest is nothing short of saving us saving humanity MR CAPEHART That is an incredible yes she is like that is a great analogy She is like Indiana Jones She is let 's talk about the first spark that drives this film and that is the killing of Trayvon Martin And in this scene that we 're about to show your character gets into gets into it with a persistent editor over the meaning of racism Watch Video plays MR CAPEHART All right So that conversation sparks a journey for Wilkerson and the movie which is as much about Wilkerson 's pursuit of an idea as it is about the idea itself Her theory is complex She writes and I quote Race in the United States is the visible agent of the unseen force of caste Caste is the bones race the skin Aunjanue how has this experience working on this film changed the way you view some of these issues of race justice and oppression MS ELLIS TAYLOR It 's changed it dramatically Dramatically I would say I would say in three ways Share this article Share First of all she 's given me language for something that I thought but did not have the language for if that makes sense MR CAPEHART Mm hmm MS ELLIS TAYLOR For example she builds her argument with these eight pillars of caste showing how her argument for caste with these sort of eight ideas and one of those ideas is how terrorism is used as a means of control I am from the rural South I am from Southwest Mississippi and I live that I live that It is a part of my life These statues these flags that are everywhere even now where I live and knowing knowing the origin of that gives me language that I did not have before knowing that these flags and these statues were not erected out of a geography we 're honoring our fallen heroes but in fact that they were they were erected to intimidate to remind newly emancipated slaves where they came from and where they could easily go back to And then also I would say it 's given me a broader understanding of how we are connected with people around the world I mean the fact that Nazis the Nazis studied Jim Crow in America to figure out the blueprint for how they would go about Nazism in Germany that blew my mind Did that not blow your mind MR CAPEHART Yeah yeah MS ELLIS TAYLOR It blew my mind And then also you know now in this present moment that we are in in this election and having a clear understanding that the way folks in the dominant caste the way that they vote their choice of who they vote for is so determined not by what they feel would be better for the country but by their insistence on maintaining the caste system in America MR CAPEHART Mm hmm So you know this is a great segue to another clip that I wanted to show In this scene Wilkerson gets some pushback on her historical theory as she has it up to that point Let 's play this We 'll talk about it on the other side Video plays MR CAPEHART There is no number And I wanted to show that because if memory serves it is after that conversation that she 's having with those friends in Germany that she then goes down the road of investigating and this is when she discovers that Nazis came to the United States to learn about the Jim Crow system and took it back there And that 's where the through line of caste from African Americans experience with slavery and further experience in the United States the Holocaust in Germany and then the caste system in India that that is where from that quote I read earlier Caste is the bones MS ELLIS TAYLOR Mm hmm Yes yes Exactly And you know one of the some of the hardest work I mean you know I have to say that when I watched that scene I get a I have n't seen the entire movie So I 've only seen clips and I see these see clips in this in situations like this where I want you know in front of other people And when I have seen it I personally I have a personal reaction to that and I watch her Isabelle 's reaction And that would not have been my reaction at all MR CAPEHART Mm hmm mm hmm MS ELLIS TAYLOR I get angry I get angry watching that And I guess that 's my character work that I had to do is because I had to respond in the way that Ms. Wilkerson would have responded not in the way that I Aunjanue Ellis responded And I have to say this That was not Isabel that was not Ms. Wilkerson 's words That was Ava DuVernay 's words And I think it 's important I think it 's important to say that because what Ava was inserting in that moment is this is this you know numberless ness Right That we can't this number that we will never know and one of the reasons why we will never know it is because the numbers keep going up They keep going up Police brutality in this country and Black people being murdered by the state that number keeps going up Sitting in that library in Germany where that those conversations actually happened and the Germans in fact the Nazis felt that they some of the things that were we were making not we but the Jim Crow South particularly were making happen institutionalizing they thought it was absurd for example intermarriage and endogamy They said There 's no way in the world we can make this happen This is ridiculous Even they even they said the links that the Jim Crow South particularly went to they said We ca n't do that That 's not possible to make happen here It 's stunning and what 's even more stunning is that we are not aware We do n't know this We do n't know this about ourselves MR CAPEHART Right You know how is it please explain to me as an actress how you have not seen the movie in full Is that something you do with all of your films or was making Origin so emotionally taxing and draining that you do n't feel ready to see it in its entirety Because I have to say from the opening scene through the end I am holding onto the what do you call it?--the armrests in the theater because it is that powerful from beginning to end Is that the reason MS ELLIS TAYLOR Well I think for me personally as an actor whatever I am you know it 's hard for me to have an experience with something and then see it translated in another form because it 's something that I went through It was something that I personally experienced And then when it's then when it 's become when it becomes something else for someone else to hold it 's not mine anymore And then it becomes it becomes vulnerable to opinion and I'm I do n't want to hear any of that My own included My own opinion you know Laughter MS ELLIS TAYLOR And Origin particularly was so personal for me I went all over the world I had experiences that changed me and I do n't want to bring my own judgment to that I want that experience to be alive in me and cherished by me and I want it to be unsullied So yeah that 's why MR CAPEHART Wow I can't we've got to talk about how this movie got made because Ava DuVernay did n't go through the Hollywood system Maybe the closest she came was going to Netflix who said Hey we want to do the film just not in 2024 So what did she do She went the philanthropic route went to our buddy Darren Walker who 's the president of the Ford Foundation and got the Ford Foundation to help finance it and individuals What do you think what kind of impact do you think that had on the film Do you think not in addition to allowing the film to be made did it give Ava and you and the other folks in the cast the freedom to make the movie that needed to be made MS ELLIS TAYLOR I love when I do interviews with Ava and she says We greenlit ourselves MR CAPEHART Laughs MS ELLIS TAYLOR I love it when she says that you know MR CAPEHART Mm hmm MS ELLIS TAYLOR That is how powerful how powerful that is She did this film outside of the studio system She made it herself She took a production all around the world She did she broke protocols She often did not have permission and I think that 's a very meta thing that she created this film without the permission of the Hollywood system without their money without any of it And she created something I think hopefully for the ages having done so And the other part of it is she would not have been able to make the choices that she made I likely would not have been in the film if it were a studio production and the other folks that I worked with maybe they would n't have been in the film as well She was able to use her own be her own boss in every way She did n't have to answer to anyone but herself Yeah I just I'm so excited by that It 's a paradigm that she 's breaking and I hope that she continues that and I hope others other filmmakers will follow in line with that MR CAPEHART Well I got a couple of questions on that One I find it surprising that you think if she 'd gone through the Hollywood system you would n't have been cast I mean you 're an Oscar nominated actress You were nominated for the Oscar for your role as Serena and Venus 's mother Williams in King Richard So that you know to my layperson 's eye once you get an Academy Award nomination you 're put in this little bucket over here of people who you know go and get the phone calls I can see the look on your face You 're like Child you do n't have any idea what you 're talking about Laughter MR CAPEHART But here 's the key thing I 'm trying to get to Do you think the fact that you guys did greenlight yourself that Ava did go outside the system that she bucked the system that that is one of the one of the reasons why Origin got nary an Oscar nomination not one MS ELLIS TAYLOR Yeah I mean you know it 's over now so we can talk about it Not only did it not get any Oscar nominations outside of the Gotham Awards it was not acknowledged or rewarded or awarded for any award I do n't know how else to say that That was that whose organization or governing body or voting body was predominantly White Not one It 's over now so I can say that you know MR CAPEHART Uh huh MS ELLIS TAYLOR Thank God that we have been honored by the Image Awards and the African American Critics Association They saw They saw us you know to continue the continue that the title the sentiment behind the title of when they see us Ava 's extraordinary work that was on about the Exonerated Five Shout out to Yusef Salaam who 's a New York City councilman right now MR CAPEHART Mm hmm MS ELLIS TAYLOR Yeah they saw us But somehow you know that community did n't MR CAPEHART And you were in you were in that show During the protests over the murder of George Floyd we saw lots of gestures made lots of things said lots of black squares on Instagram lots of people doing putting money behind a lot of things And it seems like a lot of those a lot of those things that happened have fallen by the wayside have faded away have been reversed Do you think that even what Hollywood did during that time were those just gestures or have we seen even the tiniest bit of change in Hollywood Or has it reverted back to type MS ELLIS TAYLOR Well you know a couple things First I want to say I honor and acknowledge my colleagues and my coworkers who have been nominated who were singled out and rightfully awarded for their tremendous work So I want I think both things can coexist So I want to be clear about that You know my response to that is I ca n't care I ca n't care You know I can not care I mean that 's what Toni Morrison said Right And I live by this or try to on my best days anyway is that you know that 's what this stuff does It 's merely a distraction It distracts you from your work It makes you feel that what you have to do is defend your existence defend your art And while you 're defending your existence defending your art guess what you 're not doing Is living and making your art So I ca n't care because that I ca n't care because it keeps me from doing the work that I need to do I mean thank God Ava did n't care you know and as a result of her not caring- or I 'll put it like this She did n't see that as a hurdle for her accomplishing what she achieved in Origin She did it anyway I mean that 's a very that 's a very Black church thing to say doing it anyhow Right MR CAPEHART Uh huh Laughs MS ELLIS TAYLOR That is what she did We have to do it anyhow Even when they do n't care when they do n't see us we do it anyhow Yeah MR CAPEHART Where can where can we see you next MS ELLIS TAYLOR Where can you see me next Well I 'm going to say this You know I 'm still--"Origin might be in the theaters maybe another couple weeks and my goal with this film is to make strides in penetrating the conservative community And one of those places particularly is organizations like Moms for Liberty Organizations like Mom for Liberty were instrumental in banning the book Caste in places like libraries like Texas in Texas And I feel that Origin being in the world yes it 's great I mean the great thing about Origin is that we are having these discussions now about the caste system in this country But the other part of that is what is standing in the way of our knowing that of our awareness and part of that is book banning So I 'm going to be doing work in that area to bring Origin and the book Caste again it 's already that work is already done with the book but bringing back that back to the forefront MR CAPEHART Whoo Oscar nominated actress Aunjanue Ellis Taylor star of the movie Origin This has been so much fun You know we 've gotten three minutes overtime I want to thank you-- Laughter MR CAPEHART Yes we have I want to thank you so much MS ELLIS TAYLOR Can I fan out two seconds Can I fan out two seconds MR CAPEHART Oh who am I to say no Laughter MS ELLIS TAYLOR You 're not You are not I saw you years ago at the what 's the New York Public Library the award MR CAPEHART The LION Award MS ELLIS TAYLOR Yes yes yes I think Colson Whitehead might have been might have been honored that night Yeah And you were at the you were at the end of the table and I was sitting right down And I was like oh my God there 's Jonathan Capehart So I did n't know until last night that you were going to interview me today and I 'm so excited I 'm so excited MR CAPEHART Oh wow Oh wow MS ELLIS TAYLOR Yes MR CAPEHART Well thank you very much for that Aunjanue and next time come over and say hello Laughs MS ELLIS TAYLOR Okay Done done MR CAPEHART Great This has been wonderful MS ELLIS TAYLOR Thank you Jonathan MR CAPEHART Aunjanue Ellis Taylor thank you very much for coming to Washington Post Live MS ELLIS TAYLOR Thank you Bye Bye Bye MR CAPEHART And thank you for joining us To check out what interviews we have coming up go to WashingtonPostLive.com Once again I 'm Jonathan Capehart associate editor for the Washington Post Thank you for watching Capehart on Washington Post Live
articles.author: Washington Post Live

articles.title: An obsessively vetted guide to the booming culture capital of the American West whether you 're staying in town or heading deep into the Rockies
articles.excerpt: Including an interactive Google Map to help inspire you and plan your perfect trip
articles.summary: By Welcome back to Two Night Minimum a series of city guides for those who want to get to the heart of a place in a short time be it on a business trip or a weekend vacation For this Denver edition we independently scoped out more than 90 venues and distilled the list down to the very best of the best Every recommendation below has earned our most discerning stamp of approval Ever since its establishment as a gold rush town in the 1850s Denver has been a city of transplants Never has that been more evident than in recent years with legions of work from anywhere types heeding its mile high Rocky Mountain backed call of the wild These transplants mostly millennials have become the proxy architects of the city 's fast evolving neighborhoods Retail businesses and restaurants almost always in prefabricated low rise glass buildings seem designed for social media with a cheery photo friendly patina many are popular concepts brought in from their original hometowns such as Brooklyn New York pizza icon Roberta 's and Austin sushi stronghold Uchi But if Denver feels at times like a generic catchall of Pan American culture rather than its own distinct place that 's in the process of changing The city 's economy is roaring as one of the fastest growing in the nation led by software development financial services and aerospace technology Denver International Airport already one of the largest and busiest in the US is forecasting passenger arrivals to climb from 69 million in 2019 to 100 million in the next decade That will happen just as it completes a $ 1.3 billion expansion in 2028 We 've always thought Denver was worth visiting just so we could leave typically to explore the natural wonders of the American West But it 's no longer a base camp it 's a destination in its own right Top Rooms in Town The Ramble Hotel At the Ramble rooms are decidedly Coloradan in theme with a mod cowboy aesthetic framed wildlife diagrams plaid carpeting in the hallways and plenty of leather accents But the vibe is most defined by the proudly flaunted Denver satellite of famed New York bar Death Co which takes over the parquet and concrete lobby 's velvet sofas every evening If you 're hoping for a solid night 's sleep opt for a third story room to put some distance between you and the late night shenanigans on the ground level Rates from $ 235 Source The Ramble Hotel Four Seasons Denver The predictability of Four Seasons solid hospitality feels like a life preserver in a city where the hotel scene is too often characterized by slapdash hotel themes Art Baseball surprise resort fees and $ 9 lobby cappuccinos The décor is textbook international luxury circa 2010 think cherrywood and black lacquer accents but the oversize rooms are immaculate turndown service is seamless and the on site pool and spa are the perfect way to rescue tired limbs from a long day of hiking in the nearby mountains Rates from $ 500 Source Four Seasons Denver Book It on Points Hotel Clio A part of Marriott 's Luxury Collection Hotel Clio feels significantly more upscale than the other similarly priced hotels in Cherry Creek Denver 's bougie borough Guarantee unobstructed views of the city and mountains by requesting a room on the seventh floor or higher Rates from $ 270 Source Hotel Clio a Luxury Collection Hotel Denver Cherry Creek All Day Dining Our favorite restaurants for every meal Denver is dominated by mountains and microbrews Locals start their free days with an eye toward the former either skiing or hiking and accordingly pack breakfasts to go Brunch is big Restaurants fill up first with people pouring in after exercise classes then with mountaineers returning for a patio side refuel Late afternoon beers are common antecedents to early suppers—6:30 is prime time As for post dinner drinks They only make sense when adventuring is n't on tomorrow 's agenda ● Noisette Married chefs Lillian and Tim Lu spent years working in the finest French kitchens in New York including Daniel before opening Noisette their bakery and bistro in the LoHi Lower Highland neighborhood Floor to ceiling windows pour ample sunlight across the dining room 's Napoleonic banquettes where you can have flaky pain au chocolates in the morning and savory lobster vol au vent at night both impressive feats considering the recipe rejiggering needed for oven work at altitude ● Temaki Den Reunion Bread Sushi in the landlocked Rockies seemed like an unappealing prospect until we had lunch at Temaki Den a newer venture by esteemed chef Toshi Kizaki who 's been flying in his fish from Japan 's Kyushu island daily for 40 years Go for the three roll temaki set little nori cigars filled with tuna and blue crab Then tack on a couple of orders of seared salmon oshizushi like nigiri but more tightly pressed into a brick shape Bonus Temaki Den practically shares a space with Reunion Bread they 're in the same corner of a vaulted shopping arcade where you can order a spectacular pastel de nata for dessert ● Cart Driver It feels blasphemous to say that some of the best pizza in America is in a city more famous for an omelet and even more outrageous to lavish praise on an oyster served more than a thousand miles from the ocean But Cart Driver pulls off the impossible serving the perfect high low meal of Neapolitan style pies and a dozen Wellfleets with zingy mignonette There are two branches the one in RiNo River North Art District is more casual with picnic tables in a stack of converted shipping containers whereas the LoHi locale does full table service ● No Frills Dining on East Colfax Colfax Avenue a seedy artery that tears across central Denver with its pawn shops gas stations and pay by the hour motels doubles as the surprising home to some of the city 's best unfussy eating Start a food crawl at Bastien 's Restaurant a family run institution where marbled steaks get seared with a proprietary sugar rub and slung to cowboy hatted OGs Then stop for Ukrainian bar bites including varenyky dumplings and piroshki meat pies at Molotov Kitschen + Cocktails do n't judge it by the name before hopping a 10 minute Uber ride down the street to Mango House a small food court of impressive international eats in an otherwise shuttered mall Prioritize the fried samosas and tea leaf salad at Urban Burma ● Point Easy When one of the chef owners of Point Easy died less than a month after this Whittier neighborhood spot opened in 2022 it could 've been curtains for the New American brasserie But its knowledgeable and affable staff have stayed the course turning it into what may be Denver 's best restaurant Although the menu rotates seasonally our favorites dishes were rich marsala style mushroom toast turnips lavished in vadouvan butter and a surprisingly light three meat Bolognese topped with Parmesan confetti ● Yacht Club Crank up the Fiona Apple and dim the fairy lights at this irreverent self proclaimed dive bar which feels like your older brother 's dorm room The cocktails are why you 're here mind expanding mixed drinks with bold untraditional flavors such as curry leaf and Old Bay But everything 's impeccably balanced and there 's canned Miller High Life and franks if you 're not feeling spendy On the Town Activities to squeeze into any schedule ● Get Red on the Rocks When it is n't teeming with concertgoers Red Rocks Park Amphitheatre moonlights sunlights as a do it yourself outdoor exercising arena Head there first thing in the morning for solo stair climbs or group yoga classes the latter are organized by beloved local studios River Yoga and Buffalo Sparrow Come fall the colosseum shaped venue plays host to Fitness in the City 's snow shape classes which get you ready for ski season Or if you 're not into huffing and puffing at altitude drive up the nearby Lariat Loop Trail for those TikTok worthy mountain views from the top of the aptly named Lookout Mountain ● Drink Like a Local Trickling down from Colorado 's iconic mountains is fresh alpine water perfect for brewing beer It 's one reason patios and pale ales make up the backbone of Denver 's après anything culture Try Cerebral Brewing near City Park for citrusy IPAs and laid back vibes or RiNo 's supersocial Our Mutual Friend where the small batch selection runs from sours to stouts Beyond hops there 's the unexpected Colorado Sake Co. also in RiNo which serves its own Japanese rice wine with tuna rolls and pork buns The Family Jones in LoHi sells batched cocktails made with its own distilled whiskeys and ryes you can take them home or enjoy them on site in a midcentury modern cocktail lounge set inside a large glass encased cube ● Art in the West Hidden in an unassuming downtown office building just off Broadway the American Museum of Western Art is a formerly private collection of paintings that 's now open to the public on Mondays Wednesdays and Fridays Its galleries showcase the diverse cultures and perspectives of the US frontier from the expeditionary artists of the late 18th century to modern abstract expressionism For a CliffsNotes tour eye the ethnographic portraiture in Bay 3 then jump to the third floor for some of the finest works of the Taos School which mainly produced landscapes and American Indian portraits keep an eye out for Ernest L. Blumenschein 's dreamlike depictions of New Mexico 's desert mountains and its Indigenous inhabitants For a present day take on art in the American West visit the temporary exhibition spaces at MCA Denver Past shows have repositioned the idea of the cowboy in popular culture and explored Georgia O'Keeffe 's influence on contemporary American painting ● An Interplanetary Adventure A massive mashup of sci fi and sculpture tucked between the concrete ribbons of a downtown highway interchange Meow Wolf Denver Conversion Station may be the city 's best import The interactive museum is an arcane spinoff of the original in Santa Fe New Mexico At this location memories are recorded and traded as currency in a mazelike realm where four faraway planets have suddenly collided Do n't worry if you 're confused we did n't quite understand it either but who cares The Dr. Seuss meets Grateful Dead aesthetic filled with buttons and levers that boop and boinkmakes it the perfect place to drop your kids For adults there 's a futuristic bar meant to look like an airport lounge pulled from the year 3066 Neighborhoods to Know Half day guides to two areas you should hit One central and one worth the short detour ● RiNo Many of Denver 's neighborhoods strive for a certain Nolita coolness with their funky coffee shops and cheekily abbreviated names LoDo Lower Downtown LoHi Lower Highland etc Of them all the ultra walkable River North Arts District or RiNo comes up trumps Before taking on its of the moment boutiques rewind the clock to the early 20th century when the area was the city 's hub of African American culture the Harlem of the West A self guided walking tour stretches five blocks along Welton Street taking you past former jazz halls and the only drugstore soda fountain that allowed Black and White patrons to integrate before the advent of the Civil Rights Movement Now it 's Larimer Street seven blocks away that serves as RiNo 's main artery with its surplus of colorful street art and worthy gear shops A stop at Carbon Knife Co can help you trick out your kitchen with handmade Japanese blades and collectible cookbooks carry it all home in one of the sleek backpacks from Colorado founded Topo Designs There 's good eating too be it a cortado and croissant at Hearth Bakery or snacks at the Denver Central Market The chocolate bonbons at Temper look like miniature works of postmodern art Leave room for lunch across the train tracks at Comal Heritage Food a restaurant that doubles as a small business incubator for immigrant and refugee women who churn out homespun burritos and green chili stew ● Aurora Yes it 's technically a separate city but Aurora 's manageable size and location wedged between Denver and the international airport make it a perfect stopover in between Easily the most diverse corner of Colorado Aurora is a beacon for new immigrants more than 20 of the city 's residents are foreign born and over 160 languages are spoken which for visitors yields a panoply of international shopping and cuisine Start with a snack at Bánh Butter which can go in one of two wildly different directions be it a bánh mì stuffed with fresh cilantro and jalapeño or a vanilla brûlée cruffin a croissant muffin mashup Either is a great precursor to a flight of small batch apple ales handmade by the warmhearted husband and wife owners of Haykin Family Cider For dinner Annette has garnered a fiercely loyal following for its seasonal mains it was the effortlessly cool service and even better double fried frites that won us over Get a dose of adventure on your drive in or out with a 25 minute detour through the 15000 acre Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge a wartime munitions test site turned bison reserve Or you can rocket into the air on a flight simulator at Wings Over the Rockies an aerospace museum in a former US Air Force hangar Extend Your Trip Adventures beyond the city limits Boulder equal parts mountain- and college town nuzzles up against the ridges of the Rockies just 30 miles northwest of big sibling Denver But with scores of mom and pop shops trendsetting restaurants and a dozen incredible hikes with trailheads in the middle of town it 's worth two nights all on its own Stay at one of the 60 historic cottages that make up Colorado Chautauqua a relic of the utopian late-19th century movement that brought education and entertainment to rural locales Now functioning as more of a hotel it 's a perfect gateway for hikes around the Flatiron foothills with a shared dining hall that serves Swedish style pancakes at breakfast Do as the locals and hoof it to the outskirts of town to pack a picnic lunch of artisanal charcuterie from Blackbelly before hitting the trails or snag a frothy turmeric whipped Golden Milk latte from the Boulder Dushanbe Teahouse an arabesque pavilion originally built in Tajikistan and shipped to downtown Boulder as individual pieces of timber There are three most worthy stops on Pearl Street Boulder 's main commercial thoroughfare The New Local is a gallery and studio space supporting female artists menswear shop Canoe Club features cutting edge international labels then there 's Colorado 's original fine dining outpost Frasca Food Wine which is ideal for a celebration Its prix fixe menu inspired by Alpine Italy includes indulgences such as truffled scallops and a deeply rich wild herb brodo With enough planning figure four to six weeks you can even nab the singular chef 's table located right in the kitchen A final tip before you 're on your way Ask any Coloradan The best way to earn your cred as a local is to summit all 58 of the state 's so called 14ers mountains with a peak higher than 14000 feet Most people climb a few and say they 'll eventually tackle the others The two perfect ascents to cut your teeth are Grays Peak and Torreys Peak They 're both located about an hour west of Denver with 7.5 mile hikes summits just below 14300 feet and some 3000 feet of total elevation Check out 14ers.com for detailed information the ideal time to climb is from June to early October Read next Two Night Minimum Madrid
articles.author: Brandon Presser

articles.title: Ketamine therapy for mental health a Wild West for doctors and patients
articles.excerpt: Ketamine is emerging as an alternative mental health treatment but with little regulation and varying treatment protocols it 's a medical wild west practitioners say
articles.summary: This is a KFF Health News story In late 2022 Sarah Gutilla 's treatment resistant depression had grown so severe she was actively contemplating suicide Raised in foster care the 34 year old 's childhood was marked by physical violence sexual abuse and drug use leaving her with life threatening mental scars Out of desperation her husband scraped together $ 600 for the first of six rounds of intravenous ketamine therapy at Ketamine Clinics Los Angeles which administers the generic anesthetic for off label uses such as treating depression When Gutilla got into an Uber for the 75 mile drive to Los Angeles it was the first time she had left her home in Llano California in two years The results she said were instant The amount of relief I felt after the first treatment was what I think normal is supposed to feel like she said I 've never felt so OK and so at peace For profit ketamine clinics have proliferated over the past few years offering infusions for a wide array of mental health issues including obsessive compulsive disorder depression and anxiety Although the off label use of ketamine hydrochloride a Schedule III drug approved by the FDA as an anesthetic in 1970 was considered radical just a decade ago now between 500 and 750 ketamine clinics have cropped up across the nation Market researcher Grand View Research pegged industry revenues at $ 3.1 billion in 2022 and projects them to more than double to $ 6.9 billion by 2030 Most insurance does n't cover ketamine for mental health so patients must pay out of pocket While it 's legal for doctors to prescribe ketamine the FDA has n't approved it for mental health treatment which means that individual practitioners must develop their own treatment protocols The result is wide variability among providers with some favoring gradual low dosage treatments while others advocate larger amounts that can induce hallucinations as the drug is psychedelic at the right doses A vial of Ketamine Nov. 14 2022 in Boulder Colo. Medianews Group The Denver Post via Getty Images Ketamine is the wild West said Dustin Robinson the managing principal of Iter Investments a venture capital firm specializing in hallucinogenic drug treatments Ketamine practitioners stress that the drug 's emergence as a mental health treatment is driven by a desperate need Depression is the leading cause of disability in the United States for individuals ages 15 44 according to the National Institute of Mental Health and around 25 of adults experience a diagnosable mental disorder in any given year Meanwhile many insurance plans cover mental health services at lower rates than physical health care despite laws requiring parity Thus many patients with disorders receive little or no care early on and are desperate by the time they visit a ketamine clinic said Steven Siegel chair of psychiatry and the behavioral sciences at the University of Southern California 's Keck School of Medicine But the revelation that Friends star Matthew Perry died in part from a large dose of ketamine along with billionaire Elon Musk 's open use of the drug has piqued fresh scrutiny of ketamine and its regulatory environment or lack thereof Commercial ketamine clinics often offer same day appointments in which patients can pay out of pocket for a drug that renders immediate results The ketamine is administered intravenously and patients are often given blankets headphones and an eye mask to heighten the dissociative feeling of not being in one 's body A typical dose of ketamine to treat depression which is 10 times lower than the dosage used in anesthesia costs clinics about $ 1 but clinics charge $ 600-$1000 per treatment Ketamine is still shadowed by its reputation as the party drug known as Special K Siegel 's first grant from the National Institutes of Health was to study ketamine as a drug of abuse It has the potential to send users down a K hole otherwise known as a bad trip and can induce psychosis Research in animals and recreational users has shown chronic use of the drug impairs both short- and long term cognition Perry 's death in October raised alarms when the initial toxicology screening attributed his death to the acute effects of ketamine A December report revealed Perry received infusion therapy a week before his death but that the fatal blow was a high dose of the substance taken with an opioid and a sedative on the day of his death indicating that medical ketamine was not to blame A variety of protocols Sam Mandel co founded Ketamine Clinics Los Angeles in 2014 with his father Steven Mandel an anesthesiologist with a background in clinical psychology and Sam said the clinic has established its own protocol That includes monitoring a patient 's vital signs during treatment and keeping psychiatrists and other mental health practitioners on standby to ensure safety Initial treatment starts with a low dose and increases as needed While many clinics follow the Mandels graduated approach the dosing protocol at MY Self Wellness a ketamine clinic in Bonita Springs Florida is geared toward triggering a psychedelic episode Christina Thomas president of MY Self Wellness said she developed her clinic 's procedures against a list of what not to do based on the bad experiences people have reported at other clinics The field is n't entirely unregulated State medical and nursing boards oversee physicians and nurses while the FDA and Drug Enforcement Administration regulate ketamine But most anesthesiologists do n't have a background in mental health while psychiatrists do n't know much about anesthesia Sam Mandel noted He said a collaborative multidisciplinary approach is needed to develop standards across the field particularly because ketamine can affect vital signs such as blood pressure and respiration The protocols governing Spravato an FDA approved medication based on a close chemical cousin of ketamine called esketamine are illustrative Because it has the potential for serious side effects it falls under the FDA 's Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategies program which puts extra requirements in place said Robinson Spravato 's REMS requires two hours of monitoring after each dose and prohibits patients from driving on treatment days Generic ketamine by contrast has no REMS requirements And because it is generic and cheap drugmakers have little financial incentive to undertake the costly clinical trials that would be required for FDA approval That leaves it to the patient to assess ketamine providers Clinics dedicated to intravenous infusions rather than offering the treatment as an add on may be more familiar with the nuances of administering the drug Ideally practitioners should have mental health and anesthesia expertise or have multiple specialties under one roof and clinics should be equipped with hospital grade monitoring equipment Mandel said Siegel who has researched ketamine since 2003 said the drug is especially useful as an emergency intervention abating suicidal thoughts for long enough to give traditional treatments like talk therapy and SSRI antidepressants time to take effect The solutions that we have and have had up until now have failed us Mandel said The drug is now popular enough as a mental health treatment that the name of Mandel 's clinic is a daily sight for thousands of Angelenos as it appears on 26 Adopt A Highway signs along the 405 and 10 freeways And the psychedelic renaissance in mental health is accelerating A drug containing MDMA known as ecstasy or molly is expected to receive FDA approval in 2024 A drug with psilocybin the active ingredient in magic mushrooms could launch as early as 2027 the same year a stroke medicine with the active ingredient of DMT a hallucinogen is expected to debut Robinson said many ketamine clinics have opened in anticipation of the expanded psychedelic market Since these new drugs will likely be covered by insurance Robinson advises clinics to offer FDA approved treatments such as Spravato so they 'll have the proper insurance infrastructure and staff in place For now Sarah Gutilla will pay out of pocket for ketamine treatments One year after her first round of infusions she and her husband are saving for her second In the meantime she spends her days on her ranch in Llano where she rescues dogs and horses and relies on telehealth therapy and psychiatric medications While the infusions are n't a magic fix they are a tool to help her move in the right direction There used to be no light at the end of the tunnel she said Ketamine literally saved my life

articles.title: Former Nebraska quarterback hired as FBS tight ends coach
articles.excerpt: A former Nebraska quarterback has accepted a job at an FBS school
articles.summary: A former Nebraska quarterback has accepted a job at an FBS school Joe Ganz has been hired as the tight ends coach of Middle Tennessee State Ganz has spent the last four seasons at Northern Iowa coaching wide receivers working for current MTSU offensive coordinator Bodie Reeder Blue Bomber head coach Derek Mason believes Ganz perfectly fits his team Joe has had the opportunity to work with Bodie Reeder and was with Bo Pelini at Youngstown State where they won several titles He is a winner He played quarterback which gives us another offensive mind in that room who understands the Xs and Os and how to get it from the class to the grass quickly and efficiently Ganz played at Nebraska from 2005 to 2008 During the 2008 campaign the Palos Heights Illinois native started all 13 games for the Huskers throwing for 3568 yards with 25 touchdowns and 11 interceptions By the end of his collegiate career Ganz had set 23 Nebraska school records You can find a photo articles.title: Former Husker tight end signs with United Football League
articles.excerpt: A former Nebraska tight end will be continuing his professional football career this spring
articles.summary: A former Nebraska tight end will be continuing his professional football career this spring Austin Allen has been signed by the Arlington Renegades of the United Football League Allen played for Nebraska from 2017 2021 The Aurora Nebraska native appeared in 34 games for the Cornhuskers making 65 receptions for 975 and three touchdowns During his senior season he had 38 catches for 602 yards and two touchdowns Allen was also named first team All Big Ten that season and was the Kwalick Clark Tight End of Year for the conference Following his time in Lincoln Allen would sign with the New York Giants as an undrafted free agent After being released by the Giants he would sign with the Green Bay Packers as a practice squad member for part of the 2023 season The Renegades are one of four XFL teams to move over to the UFL for the 2024 season and won the XFL Championship last year The team is coached by former Oklahoma Sooners head coach Bob Stoops Find a photo
